Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Award: Coordination Strategies for Joint State Rule

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Jordan Dalton, of the University of Michigan, will conduct new archaeological research in Peru, documenting how the expansion of the Inca Empire affected the economy of the Chincha Valley. Archaeology is unusually well positioned to answer questions pertaining to the long-term effects of state expansion, due to the long time-span with which it works. Archaeologists are able to address the dynamic effects of state expansion by documenting the effects of the initial impact of contact and local political re-organization to the cascading effects of later changes to political administration and the economy. The Chincha Valley case (in which a local group was allowed to co-administer a valley with the more powerful Inca intruders) is highly unusual, because in most cases the expansionist empire dominates smaller ethnic minorities. Dalton's research will shed new light on how the Chincha (a local ethnic group) adapted to the intrusion of the Inca Empire and will add an important case study to the understanding of how local populations cooperated and created new economic strategies. In both ancient empires and contemporary cases of expansionist states, some local strategies are retained while national and global practices are imposed. The project will provide opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, both from Peru and the United States, to collaborate and develop their skills and knowledge in archaeology. Furthermore, research will be shared with communities and students within the United States and Peru through outreach activities and articles published in both Spanish and English.

To document the changes in the political and economic administration of the Chincha Valley during Inca occupation, Dalton will excavate multiple rooms at the archaeological site of Las Huacas in the Chincha Valley, a major agricultural community occupied immediately before and during Inca occupation (A.D. 1470-1534). Dalton will expose residences, manufacturing and production areas, and discard piles of household goods in order to reconstruct which goods and crafts were manufactured, stored, and used at Las Huacas and throughout the Inca Empire. During the era of the Inca, the occupants of Las Huacas renovated their structures by laying down new floors, allowing for a fine-grained analysis of change through time. Relying on these sequences of superimposed floors, the research will document changes through time in local Chincha practices and foreign Inca practices at Las Huacas, answering questions about the impact of a foreign power on a local economy. By analyzing an array of items - including ceramic dishes, food remains, weaving instruments and farming tools, Dalton will evaluate how residents of Las Huacas affected the Inca economy as well as how the Inca affected the local economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported by Federal Award 1744365 was directed by archaeologists at the University of Michigan (Jordan Dalton and Dr. Joyce Marcus) to shed light on (1) how the Inca incorporated the people residing in the Chincha Valley into their empire and (2) how the Inca left the local Chincha lord in office and co-ruled the Chincha Valley from AD 1470-1534. Similar to today’s expansionist countries that alter the lives of the people they incorporate, ancient empires often had profound effects on the local people and the local economy. These changes can be the result of direct foreign control or they can be the result of local responses to foreign presence. The ChinchaValley provides a particularly interesting case study for the interactions between foreign and local strategies because this valley is said to have been a place where the Inca co-ruled alongside the local Chincha lord.

Excavations supported by this award focused on a high-status or elite administrative complex at the archaeological site of Las Huacas. These excavations revealed major changes to the organization and use of the area excavated, a 12m x 8m area. This area was an open space at the base of a platform in its earliest phase. Over time this complex and the room was divided into separate spaces and access to this area was restricted. Reduced access to this sector of the complex was likely tied to the rise of a more bureaucratic administration. Future research will evaluate how these changes were tied to strategies implemented by local Chincha elites and/or to the strategies of the foreign Inca officials.

The research at Las Huacas contributes another “case study” of how expansionary states and empires operate. This project involved people from the local community in Chincha as well as students and archaeoloists from both Peru and the United States. Those who worked on the project disseminated their research to local communities through public events. Peruvian students gained experience that will help them as they work towards their academic degrees, and recent graduates got experience and data to obtain their archaeology licenses. The project also created opportunities for recent graduates from universities in the United States who gained important experience before continuing their archaeological studies in graduate school. Finally, results of these excavations were disseminated to local communities in the United States through outreach events through the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History and the Society for the Advancement of Hispanic/Chicanos and Native Americans in Science.
